objects.description:
Monitor for newly executed processes that may be indicative of credential dumping. On Windows 8.1 and Windows Server 2012 R2, monitor Windows Logs for LSASS.exe creation to verify that LSASS started as a protected process.

Implementation 1 - Procdump

Detection Pseudocode
processes = filter processes where ((event_id == "10" OR event_id == "4688") AND exe == "procdump*.exe" and command_line == "*lsass*")

Implementation 2 - MiniDump via rundll32

Detection Pseudocode
processes = filter processes where ((event_id == "10" OR event_id == "4688") AND exe == "*rundll32.exe" and command_line == "*comsvcs.dll MiniDump*")

Detection Notes

- Pseudocode Event IDs are for Sysmon (Event ID 10 - process access) and Windows Security Log (Event ID 4688 - a new process has been created). - Rundll32/MiniDump has a different command-line syntax than that of Procdump, in that the process being dumped is specified via process ID instead of name (as with Procdump). Therefore, because the LSASS process ID is non-deterministic, the MiniDump detection isn’t specific to LSASS dumping and may need to be tuned to help reduce false positives.
